unit_learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate your analyses within the context of current debates on morphological theory.
Develop levels of argumentation sufficient to explain synchronic morphological and morphophonological processes, as well as diachronic processes such as grammaticalization.
Effectively communicate the importance of of morphological diversity for theoretical linguistics.
Communicate an understanding of  how linguistic typology informs other fields of linguistics.
Critically analyse morphologically complex words from a range of typologically diverse languages.
Compare and contrast word structures across language and language families.

enrolment_rules.description: 50cp at 2000 level or above including 10cp of LING units at 2000 level

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.subject_search_title: LING3383 - Morphosyntax: The Meaningful Components of Words

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This unit examines the internal structure of words, taking a typological perspective on the world's languages. It considers the interface between morphology, syntax and phonological structure. Alternative theories of word formation will be critically compared and contrasted, especially in the light of the typological diversity vs. uniformity revealed by the world's 7000 languages.
data.search_title: LING3383 - Morphosyntax: The Meaningful Components of Words
